metadata.case_name: Narasimhiah v. Vice-President and Councillors of Holenarsipur Municipality

facts.text: Appellant elected as President of Holenarsipur Municipality on September 11, 1962.
Thirteen out of twenty Councillors sent request to President to convene special general meeting to discuss no-confidence resolution, handed over on September 25, 1963.
President did not convene meeting; Vice-President called meeting.
Notice dated October 10, 1963, for special general meeting on October 14, 1963, at 10 A.M.; one copy posted at Municipal Office as per s.27(3).

Notice personally served on 15 Councillors on October 10, 1963; on R.G. Vaidyanatha on October 11; on Mirza Mohammad Hussain on October 12; on President Narasimhiah, Mr. Dasappa, and Mr. Sanniah on October 13.
Meeting held on October 14, 1963; 19 of 20 Councillors present, including President.
President claimed to preside but left the meeting; Vice-President Mr. Singri Gowda presided.
No-confidence motion passed with 15 votes in favor.
President filed Writ Petition No. 2273 of 1963 in Mysore High Court on November 2, 1963, seeking quashing of meeting proceedings and resolution.
Mysore High Court dismissed writ petition on December 6, 1963, following its decision in Writ Petition No. 2280 of 1963.

legal_issues.text: Is the requirement of three clear days' notice for the holding of a special general meeting as embodied in s.27(3) of the Mysore Town Municipalities Act, 1951, a mandatory provision?
Whether the meeting was properly held as President was not allowed to preside and Vice-President presided, contravening s.24(1)(a) of the Act.
Whether the requisition for no-confidence resolution complied with proviso to s.23(9) requiring 15 days' notice of intention to move the resolution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Requisite three days' notice not served on all members, so meeting not validly held.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.27(3) of Mysore Town Municipalities Act, 1951

petitioner_arguments.text: Meeting not properly held as petitioner not allowed to preside and Vice-President presided, contravening s.24(1)(a).
Requisition did not comply with proviso to s.23(9) as 15 days' notice not given of intention to move resolution.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Proviso to s.23(9) of the Act

respondent_arguments.text: Notices sent on October 10 deemed given on that date; provision of three days' notice is directory, not mandatory.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.27(3); High Court in Writ Petition No. 2280 of 1963

court_reasoning.text: President left meeting before Vice-President took chair; no contravention of s.24(1)(a).
court_reasoning.key_observation: It was after he left the meeting that the Vice President took the chair.

court_reasoning.text: Proviso to s.23(9) requires 15 days' notice to President only, not all Councillors; President received notice on September 25, more than 15 days before October 14 meeting.
court_reasoning.key_observation: What is required is that fifteen days notice of the intention to move the resolution has to be given to the President.

court_reasoning.text: Sending notice does not equal giving; notice to five Councillors less than three clear days.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Giving of anything as ordinarily understood is not complete unless it has reached the hands of the person.

court_reasoning.text: Provision in s.27(3) is directory, not mandatory; legislature allows shorter notice in urgency; s.36 saves resolutions from invalidity due to irregularity in notice service unless prejudicially affected.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No resolution shall be deemed invalid on account of any irregularity in the service of notice provided proceedings not prejudicially affected.

court_reasoning.text: 19 of 20 Councillors attended; 15 voted for resolution; no prejudice from short notice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Absolutely no reason for thinking that the proceedings were prejudicially affected.

holdings.text: Three clear days' notice under s.27(3) is directory, not mandatory; failure to give such notice does not invalidate proceedings unless prejudicially affected.
No contravention of s.24(1)(a) as President left before Vice-President presided.
Proviso to s.23(9) satisfied as 15 days' notice given to President.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of U.P. v. Manbodhan Lal Srivastava
precedents_cited.relevance: Provisions of Art.320(3)(c) not mandatory due to proviso allowing regulations to dispense with consultation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Writ Petition No. 2280 of 1963 (Mysore High Court)
precedents_cited.relevance: Three days' notice directory; notices sent on 10th October deemed given then.

statutes_cited.name: Mysore Town Municipalities Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs notice for special general meetings, presidency, no-confidence resolutions, and saves irregularities in notice unless prejudicial.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petition in High Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding High Court's dismissal of writ petition; held no-confidence resolution valid as notice irregularity under s.27(3) directory and non-prejudicial per s.36.

key_quotes.text: "Is the requirement of three clear days notice for the holding of a special general meeting as embodied in s.27(3) of the Mysore Town Municipalities Act 1951, a mandatory provision?"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Giving of anything as ordinarily understood in the English language is not complete unless it has reached the hands of the person to whom it has to be given."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines 'giving notice'; rejects sending as sufficient.

key_quotes.text: "No resolution of a municipal council... shall be deemed invalid on account of any irregularity in the service of notice upon any councillor provided the proceedings... were not prejudicially affected by such irregularity."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.36; key to holding provision directory.
